title: The row data's path is incorrect when sorting the table
body:
**Describe the bug**
If you sort the table so that the rows are ordered differently than initially, the path found in **_rowData.tableData.path_** remains the same, which is incorrect.

**To Reproduce**
In order to reproduce, you need to actually use the rowData.tableData.path property for some purpose, as I do. I call changeTreeExpand(path) for rows that need to be expanded. After I sort the table, that doesn't work anymore, as it will expand a different row instead which matches that path.

**Expected behavior**
The path property should be accurate also in a sorted state.

**Additional context**
**There is another path property** added directly to the Row's props (props.path) whose values are correct. I can see that these two different path properties are created separately. 

1. One within the addRow() function in data-manager.js, which runs initially. The logic is like this:

`rowData.tableData.path = [...parent.tableData.path, parent.tableData.childRows.length - 1];`

**This does not update when sorting the table, and it's the one this Bug is about.**

2. The other one is added as a prop to the Row component inside MTableBody, like this:

`path={[index + this.props.pageSize * this.props.currentPage]}`

**This one is working correctly.**


As a quick fix for now, I'm just mutating the props directly when I overwrite the Row component like this:

`props.data.tableData.path = props.path;`

title: doubleHorizontalScroll option does not work
body:
The reason is that the DoubleScrollbar component has 2 divs as children and these have the default display: block value. This means the width of the table under these divs does not get seen by the immediate child of the DoubleScrollbar and so it never appears.
If, in chrome dev tools, you change these 2 divs to have display: inline-block then it all works as expected.
I can work around this with some css I guess, but it would be good to make this the default.
see: https://github.com/mbrn/material-table/blob/master/src/material-table.js#L582

…pContext component.

## Related Issue
#1436

## Description
Allow consumers of material-table to supply a nonce that will be passed to react-beautiful-dnd's DragDropContext for CSP purposes.

## Related PRs
N/A

## Impacted Areas in Application
The DragDropContext component from react-beautiful-dnd will be impacted because it will optionally have a nonce specified for it.

## Additional Notes

title: CSP Nonce cannot be passed to react-beautiful-dnd
body:
**Describe the bug**
Material Table depends on react-beautiful-dnd.

These are the docs on setting up CSP for react-beautiful-dnd: https://github.com/atlassian/react-beautiful-dnd/blob/master/docs/guides/content-security-policy.md#option-2-use-a-nonce

There needs to be a way to pass a CSP nonce to material-table which will then pass it to react-beautiful-dnd so that a safe CSP can be used.

Currently, if you set up a CSP to use with material-table, you are forced to set the style src to unsafe-inline so that the inline styles from react-beautiful-dnd aren't blocked. The unsafe-inline directive is bad practice. Instead, material-table should allow you to specify a csp-nonce which it will pass to react-beautiful-dnd's DragDropContext.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Set up a CSP where the style src is not set to unsafe-inline
2. Use material-table

**Expected behavior**
There should be no CSP errors but there is. This is because the react-beautiful-dnd library sets inline styles.

title: Sorting strings is done by ASCII value
body:
**Describe the bug**
When sorting strings, it is done by ASCII value. When values begin by capital and lowercase, the resulting sort is not by alphabetical order:

For exemple, ['a', 'A', 'b', 'B'] gives ['a', 'b', 'A', 'B'].

**Expected behavior**
sorting  ['a', 'A', 'b', 'B'] should give ['a', 'A', 'b', 'B'].

**Solving**
To solve the problem:
compare a.toUppercase() and b.toUppercase (quick and dirty)
use localeCompare: 
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/localeCompare

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Yes, I would like to localize the date/datetime/time pickers so that my users can view the data in their locale.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Currently, the `m-table-edit-field` and `m-table-filter-row` javascript files contain `material-ui /pickers` that are wrapped with a `MuiPickersUtilsProvider` component. This component can be updated with the `locale` prop which can be supplied somehow by the user of this library so that the pickers become localized. Here is an example: https://material-ui-pickers.dev/localization/date-fns

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I haven't thought of alternatives for the moment.

**Additional context**
None.

I already had a look into the source code and as far as i understand the only possible solution would be to write custom header and row components, which is far out of scope for the requirement to make material-table completely stick to my styleguide.

So what i would really like to see are 3 new icon-keys. For example:
```
Checkbox: ReactElement
CheckboxChecked: ReactElement
CheckboxIndeterminate: ReactElement
```

Or a way to provide options to the Checkbox-components, which become used.

title: onChangePage doesn't fire when page size causes page to change
body:
**Describe the bug**
Hi, I am using the onChangePage handler to track which page the user is on. I noticed that the onChangePage event handler doesn't fire when the page change is caused by changing the page size.

**Steps to reproduce**
1. Begin on the first page with page size of 10. Results 1-10 are shown.
2. Go to the second page (all good, onChangePage is called)
3. Set page size to 20
Now results 1-20 are shown, meaning you are back on the first page. However, onChangePage never got called, so my app still thinks the user is on the second page.

Is this the desired functionality of the onChangePage handler to only be called when the user explicitly sets the page but not when the page changes through other means? Anyone know a better way of keeping track of the page?

title: Accessibility (trivial fix I think)
body:
**Describe the bug**
Chrome browser extensions that check accessibility (like WAVE and aXe) report that the table's search field is missing a form label. 

Organizations in the U.S. have been forced to pay damages for inaccessible websites, so using material-table with accessibility errors could be a problem.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Install WAVE extension on Chrome
2. Go to https://material-table.com/#/docs/features/search (or any page using search)
3. Run WAVE
4. See errors for "Missing form label", search field will be one of them

Expected behavior should be no error, there should be a visuallyhidden label "search" for that search field.

This is a great component, thanks for all your good work!

Seems like this could be a 1 minute fix for someone familiar with the codebase.

title: Set row equal to a new object, with new ref, to prevent Material-Tabl…
body:
…e from mutating variable passed through the data prop;

## Related Issue
Relate the Github issue with this PR using #1371

## Description
We are passing an array of objects from our app's Redux state to the data prop. Material Table mutates that Redux state by adding a tableData property to each object in the array. This unexpected mutation of our apps Redux state caused some of our data to be corrupted when we saved the state back to our database (now with the inclusion of the tableData property.

This pull request prevents the mutation of data described above.

title: Material-Table Mutates Item Passed Through data Prop
body:
**Describe the bug**
We are passing an array of objects from our app's Redux state to the data prop. Material Table mutates that Redux state by adding a `tableData` property to each object in the array. This unexpected mutation of our apps Redux state caused some of our data to be corrupted when we saved the state back to our database (now with the inclusion of the `tableData` property.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Pass an array of objects into the data prop.
2. console.log the array of objects on component render
3. note that each object in array now has the added `tableData` property.

**Expected behavior**
Material Table should not mutate items passed to data prop.

title: Add editActionProps
body:
New props "editActionProps" for passing props directly to the icons displayed for actions defined in the "editable" prop

## Description
The goal of this PR is to enable developers to add custom props to the icons that are being displayed for actions rendered when the `editable` prop is set.
Therefore a new prop has been introduced: `editActionProps`
`editActionProps` allows any valid Object to be passed, from which each entry will be rendered as a prop directly on the icon for the respective action.
For an example please refer to the updated Demo in `demo/demo.js` where each action gets passed a `data-test-id` as an arbitrary example. 

The reason for this was the need to identify these actions in a test-case. Custom actions were not sufficient to solve this usecase, since they do not allow for the use of the internal `editRow` as a means of data input.

## Impacted Areas in Application
For the user of this component only the main entry will be impacted. The newly introduced prop is a top-level _optional_ prop, which can me omitted if not needed.

## Additional Notes
It is, of course, entirely possible, that I am missing some way to fulfill the aforementioned usecase, and if so, I would be thankful for any feedback.

As another sidenode: This is my first time contributing to any kind of open-source project, so I may made some rookie-mistakes along the way and kindly ask for your understanding if this is the case.

Thanks for this amazing component which I intend to continuously use throughout various projects!

title: The placement of the filter row does not adhere to material design guidelines.
body:
According to the [material design guidelines on data tables](https://material.io/components/data-tables/#anatomy):

> Controls that manipulate how table data is displayed (such as pagination or filter chips) should be placed directly above or below a table.

![](https://storage.googleapis.com/spec-host-backup/mio-components%2Fassets%2F1s4W5twT0ThnL6pnchJmTdSY4uZIUDU00%2Fcomponents-datatables-filtertool.png)

Material table is currently not adhering to this guideline because the filter row is located inside the table below the header.

title: Unable to set data-testid of a table action
body:
We use automated tests that require the use of **data-testid** tags for clicks, typing, etc. For  instance for this JSX:

`<button data-testid="btn-click">click me</button>`

We would use [puppeteer](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer) to click on the button in the automated test:

`page.click('[data-testid="btn-click"]');`

We want to be able to click on a material-table row action with the automated tests. This would require adding an option to set the DOM attributes for the row actions. Something along the lines of:

```
const actions = [
    {
        id: "edit",
        icon: "edit",
        tooltip: "Edit",
        extraProps: {
             "data-testid": "btn-edit"
        }
    },...];
```

That would translate into:
`<button data-testid="btn-edit" ...>...</button>`     

Currently what we do is we use the tooltips. This is not optimal as tooltips can change and break the tests. For this row action for example:

```
const actions = [
    {
        id: "manage_snapshots",
        icon: "camera",
        tooltip: "Manage snapshots",
        onClick: () => {
            globals.history.push(`/snapshots`);
        },
    },...

```

We do this:
`await page.click('tbody tr td button[title="Manage snapshots"]');`

It is clear in this example why a tooltip change will break the test.

It is good to note that [Material-UI](https://github.com/mui-org/material-ui) main package does forward custom data attributes. So if one uses this code snippet:

```
import ButtonUI from "@material-ui/core/Button";

...

return {
     <Button data-testid="btn-submit">...
}
```

He will get a JSX along the lines of:

`<button data-testid="btn-submit">...`

Which is easy to use in automated tests, hence the request.

title: Toggle of details panel doesn't work when invoked from the search
body:
When the following code:

```
        this.tableRef.current.onToggleDetailPanel(
            [rowData.tableData.id],
            this.tableRef.current.props.detailPanel[panelToToggle].render
        );
```

 is triggered on an item in search results, a problem occurs:

```
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'tableData' of undefined
    at DataManager.changeDetailPanelVisibility (data-manager.js:399)
```


The cause of the error is on the following line:
https://github.com/mbrn/material-table/blob/master/src/utils/data-manager.js#L154

`this.findDataByPath()` doesn't find anything since `this.sortedData` is array containing only matching items (starting with index 0), while the `path` contains `rowData.tableData.id` — index of the row before the results were filtered (e.g. 82).

The problem is solved by replacing `this.sortedData` with `this.filteredData`.

title: PageSize dont change if new props in option appear
body:
**Describe the bug**
Hi, @mbrn  in material-table.js file, inside the function setDataManagerFields i recommend use the solution 
if( isInit && this.isRemoteData() ) 
{ 
    this.dataManager.changePageSize(props.options.pageSize);
}

This will avoid the problem that the table load the prop pageSize of "option" no matter if pageSize was changed manually. The reason is because if in the code some props are changed dinamically that make the pageSize change. 

For your info, just in case, and save you time
I found the commit where the actual solution was added:
Actual code:
(isInit || this.isRemoteData()) && this.dataManager.changePageSize(props.options.pageSize);

It was added in the commit 6d708f3, because the issues 1353, and released in the version 1.54.1

I checked and still acomplish

title: Fix: Misaligned placeholder text for lookup filtering
body:
## Related Issue
#1519 

## Description
Fixed misaligned filter placeholder text when using lookup filters introduced in `v1.55.0`  
Also added lookup to `Id` field in demo to easier catch similar issues in the future.

## Related PRs
Haven't found any

## Impacted Areas in Application
* MTableFilterRow
* Demo

## Additional Notes
Feel free to remove the lookup in the demo if you don't want it there, no hard feelings.

Also, I've used `px` for the negative margin on the placeholder text, the same effect can be achieved with `-1em`, not sure what you prefer here. 

I also tested a version that replaced the entire `FormControl` component with a `TextField` with the [`select` prop](https://material-ui.com/components/text-fields/#select). In that implementation there is no `margin: 0px` on the `Select` component, only a negative margin on the `TextField` component to get it inline with the non-lookup filter components. 
I can submit that version if you prefer, but  I choose to do it this way to avoid messing with too much existing code.

title: Breaking change on how props.data is handled
body:
Hello guys,

This refers to this commit:
https://github.com/mbrn/material-table/commit/ae62214079fc85a5160627faf7eeca9c51f1ec84

I put a comment there, as follows:

With this change, this.data is not holding the original references to the original objects inside the array. In line 50, you are deconstructing row (...row), which also means that if it was a named object, it becomes just a plain js object. The problem with that is:

- this is a breaking change;
- whenever you pass back the row (for example, to onRowClick), any developer will expect that to be the exact object that he passed before (as it was before this commit), but now this is a completely different reference. In a whole project that I've been using material-table, I've been relying on the fact that the rowData passed back has the same reference as the objects I passed as props.data, and now all stopped working.

Was that supposed to be a breaking change, by design?

title: Research using tannerlinsley/react-table for state
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Hello, and thank you for your hard work on such an easily customizable component!

I'm currently evaluating using this library with MUI as our new component library base at work.

Pros:
- Excellent customizations, very well thought out and ergonomic
- State is managed mostly in dataManager (not in components)

Cons:
- Test coverage on state management (dataManager)
- Test coverage on ui aspects


**Describe the solution you'd like**

This lack of tests around state management (dataManager in particular), means I am hesitant to use this component just yet, as I am trying to replace an untested complex component. Now that you are react@16.8 and above with hooks, would there be any interest in substituting state management using something like [react-table](https://github.com/tannerlinsley/react-table)? 

I would be willing to investigate if there is feature parity between both projects in my off time, but I think this would fast track the reliability aspects of this project w.r.t to state. There would really just be integration tests to make sure that state is working via ui updating correctly.

I also would prefer to not try to make a PR involving so much effort, hence the `Research` title

Cons:
- Potential increase in bundle size
- Still need ui tests

Pros:
- Reduce complexity
- Acquire tested functionality of react-table

Please let me know if this is of interest, and I will see what I can do before going down the different rabbit holes.

I've tried manually to get this data through tableRef but this isn't reliable. It would be great if in the returned data from onSelectedChange, each selected item also had a boolean to indicate if it is on the current page. Something like:

This had the unintended consequence of also changing the save button, which apparently also uses the Check icon.  I had planned on changing this icon as well to the material-ui Save icon, but can't do this since it's shared with the boolean column type.

title: MaterialTable modifying column prop directly instead of making a copy
body:
**Describe the bug**

Material Table currently modifies the column prop directly instead of making a copy first, which can cause unexpected side effects. For example, filtering a grid will save the filter state to the columns object, which will cause any future rendered grid that uses the same columns object to render with the same filter.

A similar issue was fixed in #1174 for the data prop; it needs to be extended to all props.

 

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

https://codesandbox.io/s/mystifying-resonance-iom1z?fontsize=14

1. Type something into the filter cell in the first grid

2. Click the "Show Second Grid" button

3. Second grid renders with the same filter

 

**Expected behavior**

The column prop should not be modified directly by it's child, so that other tables can use a clean version as originally defined.

So, I propose that the documentation could be edited here in github aswell. For every edit we submit a PR. I know that's an increment in the number of PRs, but I think that @mbrn could just appoint someone of his trust to do that - accept and ignore PRs that are relatable to the docs.

I don't know if that's a good feature or not, but that's something that I've been thinking for some time.

title: Support adding an ID to table, row, and cell.
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
For styling and testing purposes, it is necessary to be able to add an ID to the table and each row and cell.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Having an `id` property that can be set would solve this. For the table, this property should be able to be set directly, in the same manner as `title`. For the rows, it seems appropriate that the property should specify a prefix and then have the row number appended to it. The same could apply for cells, or the calculated ID for the row could be used and further append the column number to it. Within the column configuration, a column ID should also be able to be specified.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
n/a

**Additional context**
n/a

title: selected lookup field is getting refreshed when setStatus is touched for opening the dialogue.

title: On tree views when searching, entries stay collapsed when child elements match search
body:
Not sure if this is intended behavior, labelled as bug as to me it was unexpected.

**Describe the bug**

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create a tree view with enabled search, collapse top level rows
2. Search for a term present in a child item
3. See error

**Expected behavior**
I expect search to make all matching items visible, including child items in tree views

title: Bug/accessibility1747
body:
## Related Issue
Related to issue #1747 and issues #1375 and #1499, pulled from master and merged with and slightly modifying aitchiss's PR for #1499

## Description
Address a number of accessibility bugs preventing my organization and probably many others, from using material-table.
- addresses select checkbox aria labels, with overridable defaults (in English), including changes to TypeScript Localization interface
- addresses empty table header error for select all checkbox (accessibility docs suggest converting th to td using component={'td'})
- modifies a subset of the merged PR provided by @aitchiss in 1499, trying to maintain a closer consistency with existing localization and overrides
  - removes hardcoded English aria-label, while leaving the provided data column name (editing instructions could be different depending on picker implementation)
  - replaces hardcoded English search and filter aria-labels with new overridable [search|filter]AriaLabel, also added to TypeScript Localization
- Footer error with Broken Aria Reference - is actually a Material-UI error, see by running WAVE on https://material-ui.com/components/tables/
  - beyond the scope of this PR


## Related PRs
List related PRs against other branches:

branch | PR
------ | ------
other_pr_production | [link]()
other_pr_master | [link]()

Feature/add labels to inputs #1499 | https://github.com/mbrn/material-table/pull/1499

## Impacted Areas in Application
List general components of the application that this PR will affect:

*non-displayed HTML
*TypeScript interface Localization

## Additional Notes
This is optional, feel free to follow your hearth and write here :)
Large organizations with substantial financial assets may not use material-table out of concern for lawsuits with large cash penalties for bad accessibility.  Plus its the right thing to do.  This PR fixes many/most of those issues.

A clear and concise description of what the bug is.
Select checkboxes in header and rows have no labeling, violate accessibility, and therefore cannot be used by organizations unless they risk being sued (this is true in the U.S., so probably elsewhere).

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open material-table.com Selection, Basic Selection example in Chrome
2. Run the WAVE accessibility auditing extension
3. Checkboxes are all flagged with errors, "Missing Form Label"

**Expected behavior**
The component is accessible, developers can use it without their organizations getting sued.

**Additional context**
This is in addition to other accessibility errors, described in #1499  (which has a PR)

body:
## Related Issue
I didn't create issue. I thought it will be easier, if I simply provide solution for my problem and maybe problem of other users of Material Table

## Description
Material Table documentation (https://material-ui.com/components/tables/#custom-pagination-options) specifies that pagination can use not only options of type number, but also objects with the value and label keys, which will be used respectively for the value and label of the option (useful for language strings such as 'All').

## Impacted Areas in Application
List general components of the application that this PR will affect:

* Pagination

title: New Editable props: onRowAddCancelled and onRowUpdateCancelled has been added
body:
## Related Issue
#1596 
#1230 
#786 
#674

## Description
Sometimes, we want to make the edit-mode field type and values of one column dependent upon the value of another column, without affecting other rows. 
#1313 
During such situation, we provide value and onChange function from our component's state. Assume the user modified up-to third column and then cancelled the edit. Then we will have to reset the modifications done in our component's state. Hence, a function call is needed whenever user cancels the operation. Since cancel can be done in add and update mode, I have added two new props, onRowAddCancelled and onRowUpdateCancelled.

branch | PR
https://github.com/HarshithMjh/material-table/commit/1ecf3c0774427be93f70ed1320224ba6dc283048

## Impacted Areas in Application
There are no visual changes. Its just that the new props gets called, if the prop is supplied by the developer.

title: Add and control table footer
body:
Not talking about the footer with pagination. But the last row where you can display the sum or the percentage of one column.

The row must be fixed when navigating with pagination, must not have any empty space between this footer row and the last row of a table

We can set footer for all or just one chosen column but the number of declared footer must be the same as header columns

The footer, by default, use a **sum** function if the header of the table is of type **number**, or **percentage** with an option to specify precision after **,** or **.** (local dependent). A custom rendering function is needed, receiving the entire table data as function parameter.

If any row in a table is update or through onRowUpdate/Delete/Add, footer will be re-rendered

https://datatables.net/examples/advanced_init/footer_callback

But for some reason whenever i click the button the detail panel all open panels collapse and the dialog box does not show until after you open the detail panel up again (this is only because the dialog component is inside the detail panel as well, if put outside of it, then the detail panel closes but the dialog box appears as it should.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Have a button with dialog from "@material-ui/core/dialog" inside a detail panel 
2. Click on said button
3. See Error


**Expected behavior**
I want to add a form inside the detail panel, and with the button within it i want it to initiate a dialog prompt with "@material-ui/core/dialog" and the user returns to the open detail panel after successfully submitting the form. 

EDIT:

Codepen : https://codesandbox.io/s/3qkll63mlm?fontsize=14

I need the data={} to remain inside the render as i have a ```js
async componentDidMount() {
		this.setState({
			items: await (await fetch(`${process.env['REACT_APP_API']}/items`)).json(),
		});	
}```
which fills the items.

Edit2: It works as intended if both data and columns are outside the render.

2. I have around 20 columns so obviously i get scroll bar and wondering if pagination can be moved to left and top or configurable.
3. Ability for file upload

Let me know if any of above feature already exists or in pipeline

title: Issues when las row in a page is deleted
body:
**Describe the bug**
An error appear after the last row in the second page was deleted.

These are the messages:
"The above error occurred in the <DragDropContext> component"

Uncaught Invariant Violation: Maximum update depth exceeded. This can happen when a component repeatedly calls setState inside componentWillUpdate or componentDidUpdate. React limits the number of nested updates to prevent infinite loops.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create 2 page of element using remote connection
2. Delete the last element in the second page and the error will appear

version 1.32

title: material-table modifies global styles
body: **Describe the bug** When material-table is on screen it modifies the global styles which cause the material-ui menu drawer and more to render incorrectly. This is only since upgrading from 1.18 to 1.32 **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: 1) Run a site with a material ui menu drawer (https://material-ui.com/demos/drawers/#mini-variant-drawer) 2) Load a material-table instance in the main view **Expected behavior** Material-table does not affect components outside of it's own scope. **Screenshots** Look at drawer and back button rendering **Desktop (please complete the following information):** - OS: [e.g. iOS] OSX + Windows - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari] Chrome - Version [e.g. 22] latest
